resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
bkietz commented on pull request #6570: ARROW-7963: [C++][Dataset][Python] Expose Dataset Fragments to Python
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6570
 
 
   In C++ adds `Scanner::GetFragments`, currently only used from python.
   
   In Python adds class `Fragment` and subclass `FileFragment`. The former has only a `partition_expression` property, the latter adds a `path` property.
   
   Also in C++: deletes unused FileFragment subclasses.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

jorisvandenbossche commented on issue #6570: ARROW-7963: [C++][Dataset][Python] Expose Dataset Fragments to Python
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6570#issuecomment-597158697
 
 
   > so all true:bool, and not having the actual partition level information
   
   I thought that in your previous branch that I tested out when doing the dask POC, this actually had the partition information (because I used that for getting the partition expressions of the file path segments). 
   But rebuilding that branch, I see now this also gives all true:bool
   
   ```
   In [10]: print(f.partition_expression)  
   (true:bool and (true:bool and true:bool))
   ```
   
   But I don't understand (anymore) how this could ever give the partition information needed to reconstruct a dataset from a single file fragment.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

jorisvandenbossche commented on issue #6570: ARROW-7963: [C++][Dataset][Python] Expose Dataset Fragments to Python
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6570#issuecomment-597170529
 
 
   Argh, I of course forgot to specify the partitioning:
   
   ```
   In [1]: import pyarrow.dataset as ds 
   
   In [2]: dataset = ds.dataset("notebooks-arrow/nyc-taxi-data/dask-partitioned/", partitioning="hive")  
   
   In [3]: fragments = list(dataset.get_fragments())  
   
   In [4]: fragments[0].partition_expression 
   Out[4]: <pyarrow.dataset.AndExpression (true:bool and ((month == 10:int32) and (year == 2016:int32)))>
   ```
   
   which works nicely (I forgot the `partitioning="hive"`, it would be nice to by default "discover" if there is a partitioning scheme)
   
   Sorry for the noise.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

fsaintjacques commented on pull request #6570: ARROW-7963: [C++][Dataset][Python] Expose Dataset Fragments to Python
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6570#discussion_r390403312
 
 

 ##########
 File path: cpp/src/arrow/dataset/file_base.cc
 ##########
 @@ -148,15 +160,20 @@ FragmentIterator FileSystemDataset::GetFragmentsImpl(
   FragmentVector fragments;
   std::vector<std::shared_ptr<ScanOptions>> options(forest_.size());
 
+  ExpressionVector fragment_partitions(forest_.size());
 
 Review comment:
   The current layout is misleading; the `partitions_` property should hold the full partition expression of every path. We should store the simplified expressions, i.e. with ancestors' partitions assumed, in a separate property, e.g.
   
   ```c++
   // The full expression partition of every path.
   ExpressionVector partitions_;
   The simplified expression of every path, e.g. the parent's partitions assumed into the child partition.
   ExpressionVector simplified_expressions_;
   ```
   
   This will also affect the writing path.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

users@infra.apache.org

fsaintjacques commented on pull request #6570: ARROW-7963: [C++][Dataset][Python] Expose Dataset Fragments to Python
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6570#discussion_r390403312
 
 

 ##########
 File path: cpp/src/arrow/dataset/file_base.cc
 ##########
 @@ -148,15 +160,20 @@ FragmentIterator FileSystemDataset::GetFragmentsImpl(
   FragmentVector fragments;
   std::vector<std::shared_ptr<ScanOptions>> options(forest_.size());
 
+  ExpressionVector fragment_partitions(forest_.size());
 
 Review comment:
   The current layout is misleading; the `partitions_` property should hold the full partition expression of every path. We should store the simplified expressions, i.e. with ancestors' partitions assumed, in a separate property, e.g.
   
   ```c++
   // The full expression partition of every path.
   ExpressionVector partitions_;
   // The simplified expression of every path, e.g. the parent's partitions assumed into the child partition.
   ExpressionVector simplified_expressions_;
   ```
   
   This will also affect the writing path.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

bkietz commented on pull request #6570: ARROW-7963: [C++][Dataset][Python] Expose Dataset Fragments to Python
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6570#discussion_r390461027
 
 

 ##########
 File path: cpp/src/arrow/dataset/file_base.cc
 ##########
 @@ -148,15 +160,20 @@ FragmentIterator FileSystemDataset::GetFragmentsImpl(
   FragmentVector fragments;
   std::vector<std::shared_ptr<ScanOptions>> options(forest_.size());
 
+  ExpressionVector fragment_partitions(forest_.size());
 
 Review comment:
   I disagree; as previously discussed including the partition information of every parent is redundant and breaks the efficiency of pruning directories (since a parent directory's partition expression will be evaluated for every fragment contained in it)
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

bkietz commented on issue #6570: ARROW-7963: [C++][Dataset][Python] Expose Dataset Fragments to Python
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6570#issuecomment-597197085
 
 
   > We should be able to list fragments without going through the Scanner/ScanOptions hoops. This exposes a flaw with the current API where it require a ScanOptions to create Fragment
   
   I don't see why this is a flaw. Please open a follow up ticket for the changes you describe; we can discuss whether Fragments should have ScanOptions there. I don't think it's relevant to this PR because ScanOptions are not even exposed in Python.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

jorisvandenbossche commented on issue #6570: ARROW-7963: [C++][Dataset][Python] Expose Dataset Fragments to Python
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6570#issuecomment-597203492
 
 
   > if required, we can still provide an alternate signature, e.g. Dataset::GetFragments(std::shared_ptr<Expression> predicate) for sub-tree pruning in FileSystemDataset.
   
   Yes, this would indeed be needed in such a case (eg I was using this pruning of the fragments in dask, to avoid many "empty" fragments/tasks)
   
   ---
   
   I don't know the C++ details, but *conceptually* I think I agree with @fsaintjacques on the feeling that you should not necessarily need ScanOptions to list fragments (but on the python side this is indeed alread hidden for the user)
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

fsaintjacques commented on issue #6570: ARROW-7963: [C++][Dataset][Python] Expose Dataset Fragments to Python
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6570#issuecomment-597260070
 
 
   The python side does indirectly construct a ScanOptions via the Scanner constructor. As a mater of fact, the `column` parameter of python's `Dataset.get_fragments` has no effect since the projector is not even applied in `Scanner::GetFragments`.
   
   My point is, `Scanner::GetFragments` shouldn't exist, `Dataset::GetFragments` should suffice for introspection. The reason it can't is because we need a ScanOptions to create a Fragment. The fact that Python's `Dataset.get_fragments` calls C++ `Scanner::GetFragments` and not C++'s `Dataset::GetFragments` as currently implemented just reinforce this point, it introduces confusion.
   
   The pr adds a method to Scanner, the class which is a closure that generates RecordBatches, to introspect its internals, which really are Dataset internals, and immediately drop the closure without actually calling it (consuming said RecordBatches). All of this to call Dataset::GetFragments by using the Scanner's option. This points to a design flaw. The way to break it, is to remove the cycle between Dataset, Fragment, and any Scan* related classes. I added [ARROW-8065](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-8065) for this.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6570#issuecomment-597295916
 
 
   FWIW: `columns` *is* used here: the resulting fragments' schemas contain only fields referenced in that (but fragment schema isn't currently exposed in Python so it's not visible that `columns` is used)

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.

fields.description: It would be useful to able to list the fragments, to get their paths / partition expressions.
